race.name: Gravel Worlds
race.tagline: 150 miles of relentless Nebraska rollers. $100K purse. Pirate swords for winners. The grassroots championship.

vitals.prize_purse: $100,000 (World Championship jerseys + Sword Trophy for 'Captain of the Gravel Seas')
vitals.aid_stations: Multiple aid stations at key points

climate.description: August brings humidity, heat, and the kind of Midwest summer that tests your heat tolerance

terrain.primary: Classic Nebraska farm gravel with minimum maintenance roads
terrain.surface: Loose gravel, some rough minimum maintenance, occasional sand/mud

gravel_god_rating.score_note: The OG grassroots race since 2010. 'World Championship' title, $100K purse, Pirate ethos. Overall +6 for cultural significance.

logistics.explanation: First-come registration on BikeReg eliminates lottery drama, but $195 entry plus Lincoln travel adds up. Carey Lowery experienced a navigational error that "cost me 60 minutes and gave me 17 bonus miles," highlighting route-finding challenges. Two official checkpoints provide basic support, though the 15.5-hour cutoff proved unforgiving in 2024 when only 97 of 150 starters finished within time.

length.explanation: Carey Lowery's race strategy reveals the 150-mile grind: "Last year it took 3:25 to go 54 miles; this year, 4:30. I was over an hour behind last year's time." His mental approach at "miles 80-100 were the hardest for me, as I was beginning to tire from the monotony" captures how this distance breaks riders through sheer persistence rather than single epic moments. Among the longest in gravel, comparable to Badlands.

technicality.explanation: Nebraska's "small pea gravel/sand mixture" becomes treacherous when wet—Lowery described hitting B-roads around mile 70: "I felt like I was on a single track ribbon of dark chocolate. There was a 18 inch wide path of firm ground on this road, but to either side it was sticky mud." The gravel "soaked it up like a sponge" rather than shedding water like other regions. Similar technical demands to SBT GRVL.

elevation.explanation: The 10,000 feet over 150 miles creates what one veteran described as "intervals for 4 hours straight"—87 relentless rollers through Nebraska's drainage hills. These constant power surges through rolling farmland prove harder than single big climbs, as riders are either climbing or descending with virtually no recovery flats to settle into rhythm. Similar elevation profile to Almanzo 100.

climate.explanation: Late August Nebraska heat proved brutal in Carey Lowery's 2023 race: pre-race conditions hit "100+ degrees and the gravel was dusty," then overnight storms dumped 2.5 inches of rain, creating a chilly 69-degree start that eventually turned steamy. The combination of mud, then sun and humidity as "roads were still sludge" demonstrates how prairie weather can compound suffering. Among the most weather-friendly events, easier than Badlands.

altitude.explanation: Lincoln sits around 1,200 feet—essentially sea level for cycling purposes. Your cardiovascular system won't notice the elevation, but it will definitely notice the Nebraska heat and humidity that dominate the late August prairie conditions. Lower altitude than The Mid South — no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: Beyond standard gravel roads, the course includes "cobble-filled alleyways, brief singletrack, and dirt roads that become mud gambles when storms hit." The 300-mile Long Voyage crosses three states into Iowa and Missouri. Weather adds unpredictability—Lowery's race transformed from "dusty" pre-race conditions to "chocolate smoothie" mud after overnight storms.

prestige.explanation: 16-year history from grassroots to $100K prize purse. The 'World Championship' branding is bold but earned through longevity. Pirate sword trophies are iconic. Part of gravel's original DNA.

race_quality.explanation: Well-organized with checkpoint support, convenience store stops mapped, and proper timing. The 'gravel family' ethos means inclusive vibes. They celebrate last-place finishers with 40 bottles of champagne. As Checkpoint Features puts it: "There was a short, 0.4 mile cross course I had to do, including riding through a barn, before I hit the aid station."

experience.explanation: The combination of pirate theme, Nebraska heat survival, and relentless terrain creates defining memories. Lowery finished in 11:34 to find "Jason Strohbehn (the face of Gravel Worlds) was there to give me a fist bump. Volunteers handed me an ice cold Coke and a wet towel." The personal touch from organizers at the finish line caps a day of Nebraska suffering.

community.explanation: Peak grassroots gravel culture. 'Be Cool' is Rule #1. The pirate aesthetic, the inclusive spirit, the celebration of all finishers. This is what gravel community looks like. As Carey Lowery puts it: "I love the vibes of Gravel Worlds and how no one is more important than another. We are all equal here! The race organizers are wonderful people and have their shit dialed! They work tirelessly for da..."

field_depth.explanation: The $100K purse (2025) draws serious pros. The 300-mile Long Voyage attracts ultra specialists. Age-group competition is strong with Midwest cycling clubs well-represented. Deeper field than most — comparable to Badlands. As Matt Beers puts it: "It was really fun to go to the line with one of my best mates. We played our cards and attacked in the right spots."

value.explanation: Lowery's assessment captures the value proposition: "The race organizers are wonderful people and have their shit dialed!" For $195, riders get checkpoint support, pirate sword finisher awards, and what amounts to a multi-day festival experience. The personal attention—race director Jason Strohbehn greeting finishers with fist bumps—justifies premium pricing for this level of event production.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $150. Lincoln is affordable. Hotels are reasonable. Flights to LNK or OMA are manageable. Midwest pricing keeps costs down compared to coastal events. More affordable than Crusher in the Tushar.

biased_opinion.summary: Gravel Worlds represents what the sport was before corporate money arrived. It's authentic, community-driven, and legitimately hard. The 'World Championship' name started as a joke but the race earned its reputation through genuine challenge.
strengths: Authenticity: Grassroots soul in a corporatized sport.
The community: Pirate culture means inclusive, welcoming energy.
The challenge: 150 miles in August Nebraska heat is no joke.
weaknesses: The heat: August humidity and heat can be punishing.
Nebraska: Not a tourist destination. You're here for the race.
Infrastructure: Less polished than Life Time events.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: If you want to experience what gravel racing meant before it went mainstream, Gravel Worlds is your pilgrimage. Harder than it looks, more meaningful than its name suggests.

final_verdict.one_liner: The OG grassroots gravel race—where the spirit of the sport lives on in Nebraska summer heat.
final_verdict.should_you_race: Yes if you value authenticity, community, and genuine challenge over polish. Yes if you can handle August Midwest heat. Not if you need corporate production value.
final_verdict.alternatives: If you want heat without the distance: Unbound 100. If you want distance without the heat: fall ultra events. If you want grassroots elsewhere: local favorites.

logistics.airport: Omaha (OMA) - 1 hour. Lincoln (LNK) - 15 minutes but limited flights.
logistics.lodging_strategy: Lincoln has ample hotels. Book 1-2 months ahead.
logistics.food: Lincoln has solid food options. Not a foodie destination but functional.
logistics.packet_pickup: Friday at event venue. Grassroots vibe, efficient process.
logistics.parking: Start area parking is generally available.

history.founder: Corey Godfrey / Gravel Cycling Hall of Fame
history.origin_story: 'Exploring together since 2010.' Started as a tongue-in-cheek 'World Championship' for a sport that didn't have one. 15+ years later, it's a legitimate bucket-list event with $100K prize purse. Winners earn 'Captain of the Gravel Seas' title and a Sword Trophy. Now includes running series (16mi) and gravel triathlon.
notable_moments: One of the original grassroots gravel races
Created the 'Pirate' ethos in gravel culture
Gravel Cycling Hall of Fame is based here
history.reputation: The OG grassroots race. Where the gravel movement's spirit lives on.

course_description.character: Long, hot, and humbling. NOT flat—'hill after hill after hill' averaging 4-5% grade either up or down the entire 150 miles through iconic cornfields. 10K+ feet of climbing with no single killer climb, just relentless rolling. Mud possible in wet years.

suffering_zones.label: Heat Onset
suffering_zones.desc: Morning cool is gone. The Nebraska sun starts earning its reputation.

suffering_zones.label: Century Club
suffering_zones.desc: You've done 100 miles. There's 50 more. In August heat.

suffering_zones.label: Mind Games
suffering_zones.desc: Close enough to finish to hurt. Far enough to break.

course_description.signature_challenge: The heat. August in Nebraska is oppressive. Heat adaptation isn't optional—it's survival.
